titleproper.value: Guide to the New-York Historical Society Bequests, Gifts & Related Matters Record Group<lb/>1852-1992<lb/> <num>NYHS-RG 16</num>

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2019-08-29T17:23:04</date>

unittitle.value: New-York Historical Society bequests, gifts & related matters

abstract.value: The New-York Historical Society bequests, gifts & related matters record group (NYHS-RG 16) primarily includes records concerning estates in which N-YHS was named as a beneficiary. Most of these instances resulted in N-YHS receiving museum objects, manuscripts, books, or other items or a financial legacy. The record group also includes files of some donations of objects and funds from donors during their lifetimes, as well as some purchases. The record group includes files on some of the most important patrons and objects in N-YHS's history.

p.value: Series I is open to qualified researchers. The other three series, generally holding records from post-1960 transactions, are restricted. N-YHS restricts certain of its records, such as those in this record group, for fifty years from the conclusion of the tenure of a Director/Chief Executive Officer.
This record group should be cited as New-York Historical Society bequests, gifts & related matters (NYHS-RG 16), The New-York Historical Society.

The record group includes files on some of the major patrons and objects in N-YHS's history, including the Beekmans, Belknaps, Thomas J. Bryan, Crawford's sculpture <emph render="italic">The Indian</emph>, the Gallatin family, Cass Gilbert drawings, the Livingstons, Katharine Prentis Murphy, James Lenox's Nineveh sculptures, Katherine R. Rogers, the Thompson family, and many others. The container list includes a detailed inventory of the files.

subject.value: Museums -- Acquisitions -- New York (State)  -- New York.

dsc.value:
Series I. Bequests to Circa 19605.42 Linear feetin 13 document boxes1852-1986Scope and Contents Note

This series includes records of bequests and other gifts from 1852 to about 1960. Given that every file in the series represents a completely different matter and that the files span about 100 years of donations, the subject content of each file is noted in the container list. Many of the files include rich documentation including that for many acquisitions important in N-YHS's history, among them gifts and/or bequests from Thomas J. Bryan, Gerard Beekman (family coach), Waldron Phoenix Belknap, Jr. and his mother, Rey Hutchings Belknap, the Gallatin family, John Divine Jones, the Robert Livingston family, Pirie MacDonald, and Katharine Prentis Murphy and her brother, Edmund Astley Prentis. The series includes extensive documentation of the large financial legacy received from the Thompson family estate that was used to expand the Central Park West building and N-YHS's programs and staff in 1937-38. Among the major accessions documented in the series are Thomas Crawford's sculpture The Indian (from Frederic de Peyster), the drawings of architect Cass Gilbert, ancient Nineveh sculptures (from James Lenox), and bronze models by sculptor John Rogers (from his daughter, Katherine). The series includes some purchases, such as the Robert Bracklow photographs from Alexander Alland, portrait paintings from artist DeWitt Lockman, the Nadelman folk art collection, and Leonidas Westervelt's Jenny Lind collection.

In addition to acquisitions from individuals, the series also holds files on some institutions that donated or deposited their records to N-YHS, or considered the possibility. Among these is the 1938 proposal, eventually declined, of the donation of the collections of the Marine Museum of the City of New York to N-YHS. Other institutions include, among others, the Naval History Society; the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the U.S., Commandery of the State of New York; the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States; and the Sons of Rhode Island in New York.

Some files include subjects tangentially related to the bequest or gift itself. These include the exhibition of the Belknap Collection in 1950; the installations of the Prentis-Murphy Collection (1950s) and the Nadelman Folk Art Collection (circa 1940); the 1912 New York State court case concluding that N-YHS was an educational institution for the purpose of exemption from a transfer tax on bequests (De Peyster, C. Augusta file); the financial records for production of the first volume paid from the John Divine Jones Fund; and the successful effort to overturn the directive in the will of Augustus Van Horne Stuyvesant, Jr. to destroy much of his property. Generally the cut-off for this series is 1960, but there are later documents in the series that are included as they relate to the earlier transaction.

Arrangement Note

The series is arranged in alphabetical order by name. The names were generally taken from the original folders, and typically are the name of an estate, donor, lender, seller, or other source of an object or funds. Some names, though, refer to the item received.

Statement of Legacies and Estatescirca 1935-194111Scope and Contents Note

Appears to be a list of pending wills and estates in which N-YHS was named as a legatee, as of circa 1935 with annotated updates to circa 1941.

Abeel, George1912-193112Scope and Contents Note

Bequest of Abeel and Duyckinck family portraits and funds for their care. File includes photographs of the portraits (accessions 1918.1, 1918.2, 1918.6, 1918.8, 1918.9, 1918.19).

Principally includes documents related to George T. and William G. Mortimer (obituaries, photographs, extract from George's will, and George's honorable discharge from the 71st Regiment of New York (1901). Also includes the printed "Memoir of Cyrus Cornelius Adams."

Beekman, Gerard (2 folders)1909-1913, 1919, 1946-1948116-17Scope and Contents Note

Includes a copy of the certificate of incorporation of the Beekman Family Association and deeds of gifts to it from Gerard Beekman, and related documents (1909-1910, 1913); gift of Beekman to N-YHS of the family coach, room linings and parts of the entrance from the Turtle Bay house (1911), with funds for the care of the objects; notice of probated will (1919); lists of Beekman family objects at N-YHS (1946) and related documents.

Belknap Collection (6 folders)1944-1963118-23Scope and Contents Note

Includes gifts, bequests, and loans from Waldron Phoenix Belknap, Jr. (died 1949) and his mother, Rey Hutchings Belknap (died 1960), and other correspondence related to particular objects. Includes correspondence and other matter related to the 1950 exhibition of the collection. Includes the loan receipts and other documents, both from Mrs. Belknap and various institutions, for the 1955 exhibition of colonial portraits derived from English mezzotint engravings.

Other topics are also included in the files, including an attempt by Gitelson's daughter, Susan Aurelia Gitelson, with N-YHS's support, to establish an essay contest at Barnard College and Gitelson's attempt (declined) to publish an article in N-YHS's Quarterly.

Naval History Society1924-1926, 1977723bScope and Contents Note

Includes documents related to Franklin D. Roosevelt's proposed amalgamation of the Ship Model Society, Marine Society, and Naval History Society with N-YHS (1924); includes a document that is likely Roosevelt's proposal, Alexander J. Wall's notes of a Ship Model Society meeting at which the proposal was discussed, and a report of a visit to Roosevelt by N-YHS representatives. Also includes documents related to the donation of the Naval History Society's collection and to N-YHS and the establishment of the Naval History Fund (1925-26). Documents from 1977 relate to the publishing of select materials from the collection.

Prentis, Edmund Astley1950-1952813Scope and Contents Note

Gift, with Katherine Prentis Murphy, of colonial furniture and its installation in rooms at N-YHS. Gifts of paintings, court cupboard, spoons, and other objects. Financial contributions. Conveyance of gift from Mrs. Blake Donaldson of an 1864 publication. Includes a roughly drawn organization chart of N-YHS done by director Vail for Prentis at his request as a new trustee. See also folders above for Murphy, Katharine Prentis and below for Prentis-Murphy Collection.

Prentis-Murphy Collection (4 folders)1949-1982814-17Scope and Contents Note

Inventories of gifts and loans and summaries of expenses related to the collection (1950-53). Correspondence concerning acquisition (1949-50). Magazine articles. Correspondence concerning the collection (1951-53). Copies of the final wills of Katharine Prentis Murphy and Edmund Astley Prentis (1964-67). Some correspondence concerning the decision to dismantle the Prentis exhibition rooms, thereby relinquishing the collection to Columbia University (1981-82). See also folders above for Prentis, Edmund Astley and for Prentis-Murphy Collection.

Gift of objects to N-YHS from the estate following the court decision to not follow will's direction (1956-57).
